The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.2 is: A for loop shall be well-formed. The three clauses of a for statement are the: 1. First clause shall be empty or an expression whose set the value of the loop counter or define and intialize the loop counter. 2. Second clause shall be an expression that has no persistent side effects, and shall use the loop counter and optionally loop control flags, and shall not use any other object that is modified in the for loop body. 3.Third clause shall be an expression whose modify only the value of the loop counter, and shall not use objects that are modified in the for loop body. 4. There shall only be one loop counter in a for loop, which shall not be modified in for loop body. A loop control flag is defined as single identifier denoting an object with Boolean type that is used in the second clause. The behaviour of a for loop body includes the behaviour of any functions called within that statement. Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines. They will investigate the code fragments you give. Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule. Provide your answer with these fields. - suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code. It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags - explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated. It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated. DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments. \n", language->longname); if (0 >= res) continue; /* snprintf() error */ if (rdc.buf_len - rdc.off <= (size_t) res) continue; /* buffer too small?? */ rdc.off += (size_t) res; for (category_idx = 0; NULL != categories[category_idx]; category_idx++) { category = categories[category_idx]; res = snprintf (dir_name, sizeof (dir_name), "%s/%s", language->dirname, category); if ((0 >= res) || (sizeof (dir_name) <= (size_t) res)) continue; /* cannot print dir name */ if (0 != stat (dir_name, &sbuf)) continue; /* empty */ /* we ensured always +1k room, filenames are ~256 bytes, so there is always still enough space for the header without need for an additional reallocation check. */ res = snprintf (&rdc.buf[rdc.off], rdc.buf_len - rdc.off, "

\n", category); if (0 >= res) continue; /* snprintf() error */ if (rdc.buf_len - rdc.off <= (size_t) res) continue; /* buffer too small?? */ rdc.off += (size_t) res; if (MHD_NO == list_directory (&rdc, dir_name)) { free (rdc.buf); update_cached_response (NULL); return; } } } /* we ensured always +1k room, filenames are ~256 bytes, so there is always still enough space for the footer without need for a final reallocation check. */ len = strlen (INDEX_PAGE_FOOTER); if (rdc.buf_len - rdc.off <= len) { /* buffer too small */ free (rdc.buf); update_cached_response (NULL); return; } memcpy (rdc.buf, INDEX_PAGE_FOOTER, len); rdc.off += len; initial_allocation = rdc.buf_len; /* remember for next time */ response = MHD_create_response_from_buffer_with_free_callback (rdc.off, rdc.buf, &free); mark_as_html (response); #ifdef FORCE_CLOSE (void) MHD_add_response_header (response, MHD_HTTP_HEADER_CONNECTION, "close"); #endif update_cached_response (response); } ``` Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. explanation: I flagged both for-loops in the function for investigation because Rule 14.2 concerns the three clauses of a for statement and interactions between the clauses and anything (including called functions) that may modify the objects used in those clauses. The second clauses use expressions that index into arrays (languages[language_idx].dirname and categories[category_idx]) and the body calls functions (stat, snprintf, list_directory, etc.). Those functions or other code reachable from the loop body could modify objects used in the loop clauses; that possibility must be checked. Other code fragments were not flagged because they are not loop headers or do not affect the validity of the for statement clauses per Rule 14.2: - Buffer allocation, memcpy, strlen, rdc.off arithmetic and the footer handling do not form for statements and do not appear in any for-clause expressions. - There are no other for/loop headers in the function to inspect. - Local assignments (e.g. language = &languages[language_idx]; category = categories[category_idx]; rdc.off += (size_t) res;) occur in the loop body and do not appear in the second/third clauses. Therefore they are not directly relevant to whether the for statements are well-formed under Rule 14.2; only the for headers and any functions reachable from their bodies need examination.
